title: Introduction
description: JavaScript is a programming language used to make web pages interactive. It runs in the browser and allows you to respond to user actions.
task: Print 'Hello, JS!' to show the output using console.log().
dialogue: A wooden sign creaks at the town gate.
The name echoes in your memory.
Something here made the town respond.
The reason everything here once felt alive.
hints: Use console.log() to print output.
Your code should run without errors.

title: Console Output
description: When you are working with a programming language, you want to execute some logic and then see the output, or display the final output. Right?, In JavaScript, to display output,  The console.log()function can be used multiple times to print different outputs to the console in sequence.
task: Print 'Hello' on the first line and 'World!' on the second line using console.log().
dialogue: You notice strange symbols carved into a terminal.
When you speak through it, the town listens.
Messages appear‚Ä¶ but only to those who know where to look.
This must be how the town communicates.
hints: Put your message inside the parentheses.
Remember to wrap text in quotes.

title: Variables
description: A variable in JavaScript is a named memory space that is used to store a value. A variable is like a container in which you can store any data or value. Use var, let, or const to create variables.
task: Create three variables named playerName, score, and isOnline. Assign them the values 'Nova', 120, and false. Then change isOnline to true and print all three variables to the console on separate lines.
hints: Variables can be reassigned after declaration
Boolean values are true or false (without quotes)
Use console.log() to print each variable
dialogue: The town asks for a name.
Not everything here is fixed‚Äîsome things can be stored, remembered.
You bind a name to an idea.
For the first time, the town recognizes you.

title: Data Types
description: In a programmer‚Äôs adventure, a variable is like a chest, and the data type is the magic that controls it. It decides what kind of treasure can be stored inside and how much space the chest has. Choosing the right data type keeps your journey safe and your program strong. JavaScript supports different data types such as strings, numbers, and booleans.
task: Create three variables named userName, lives, and hasKey. Assign them the values 'Aria', 3, and false. Print all three values to the console on separate lines.
hints: Strings must be wrapped in quotes
Numbers are written without quotes
Booleans are either true or false
dialogue: You start to see patterns in the town‚Äôs thoughts.
Each idea has a different shape.
Now you understand how the town thinks.

title: Function Basics
description: Functions are reusable code blocks designed to perform a particular task. At its core, a function is simply a way for the creator (you), to package a set of instructions that can be called at-will to do a task. Learn how to define and call functions in JavaScript.
task: Create a function named showMessage that prints 'Welcome!' to the console. Call the function twice.
hints: Use function keyword.
Call the function after defining it.

title: Parameters & Arguments
description: Parameters and arguments are used when working with functions. Parameters act like placeholders in a function definition, while arguments are the actual values passed to the function when it is called. They allow functions to receive data, making code more flexible and reusable.
task: Create a function named greet that takes a parameter name and prints 'Hello ' followed by the name. Call the function with the argument 'Jet'.
hints: Define a parameter in the function.
Use it inside console.log.

title: Return Values
description: Functions can return values using the return statement. When JavaScript reaches a return statement, the function stops executing. The return statement stops function execution and returns a value to the caller.
task: Create a function named multiply that takes two parameters x and y, returns their product, and prints the returned value when the function is called with arguments 4 and 5.
hints: Use return to send a value back from the function
The function stops running after return
Use console.log() to print the returned value

title: Arrow Functions
description: Did you know that Arrow Functions were introduced in ES6 and are commonly used in modern JavaScript. A shorter syntax for writing functions using arrow functions. You can skip the function keyword, the return keyword, and the curly brackets:. Arrow functions in JavaScript are a concise way to write functions using the => syntax, automatically binding this from the surrounding context.
task: Create an arrow function named welcome that takes a parameter user and prints 'Welcome ' followed by the user name. Call the function with the argument 'Jet'.
startingCode:
const welcome = user => 

// call the function here
hints: Use the => arrow syntax
You can write console.log() on the same line
Call the function after defining it

title: Arrays
description: An Array is an object type designed for storing data collections. Storing multiple values in an array. In JavaScript, an array is an ordered list of values. Each value, known as an element, is assigned a numeric position in the array called its index. The indexing starts at 0, so the first element is at position 0, the second at position 1, and so on.
task: Create an array named fruits containing 'Apple', 'Banana', and 'Orange'. Print the second item in the array to the console.
startingCode:
let fruits = [];

// print the second item
hints: Array indexes start at 0
The second item is at index 1

title: Array Methods
description: JavaScript provides a wide variety of array methods. These methods allow you to add, remove, find, and transform array elements with ease. Learn to manipulate arrays using push(), pop(), and other methods.
task: Create an array containing the numbers 1, 2, and 3. Remove the last number using pop(), then print the array to the console.
hints: Use pop() to remove the last element
pop() changes the original array

title: Objects
description: An Object is a variable that can hold many variables. Store data using key-value pairs.
task: Create an object named car with properties brand set to 'Tesla' and year set to 2024. Print the year property to the console.
hints: Use curly braces {} to create an object
Properties are written as key: value
Access object properties using dot notation

title: Object Methods
description: Objects can have methods (functions) as properties.Object Methods in JavaScript can be accessed by using functions. Functions in JavaScript are stored as property values. The objects can also be called without using brackets ().
task: Create an object named robot with a method named speak that prints 'Beep!' to the console. Call the speak method.
hints: Methods are functions inside objects
Use () to call an object method
Access methods using object.method()

title: Selecting Elements
description: Selecting elements in JavaScript allows you to access and interact with parts of a web page. By using different selector methods, you can find HTML elements by their id, class, tag name, or other attributes. This is essential for changing content, styles, or behavior dynamically. Learn how to select HTML elements using document.querySelector or getElementById.
task: Select a paragraph element with the id 'message' and print its text content to the console.
startingCode:
let elem = document.getElementById('');

// print the text content
hints: Use document.getElementById() to select by id
The id value should not include #
Use textContent to read the text

title: Modifying Content
description: The HTML DOM allows JavaScript to change both the text and the content of HTML elements. The easiest way to get the content of an element is by using the innerHTML property. The innerHTML property is useful for getting or replacing the content of HTML elements.   Change the content of HTML elements using JavaScript.
task: Select an h1 element and change its text content to 'Hi!'.
hints: Select the element first.
Assign new text using textContent.

title: Event Listeners
description: The addEventListener() method attaches an event handler to the specified element. Respond to user actions by adding event listeners.
task: Add a click event listener to a button that prints 'Clicked!' to the console when clicked.
hints: Use addEventListener.
Use an arrow function to define the callback.

title: Dynamic Styling
description: We can modify the style of DOM objects by using the style object found in DOM elements. The style object allows us to alter a variety of things, such as text color, background color, object animation, size changes, displaying and hiding portions of a page, pop-up box creation, and more.
task: Select an h1 element and change its color to red.
hints: Select the element first.
Change the style property.

title: JavaScript Exam
description: Test your JavaScript knowledge by solving exercises covering all previous modules.
task: Create a function that takes two numbers as parameters and returns their sum. Call the function with the numbers 5 and 7, and print the result to the console.
hints: Use functions, variables, arrays, objects, and DOM manipulation.
Test your code carefully.
